Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the demand for food will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the poor. This will be a challenge to meet because of the effects of climate change. Here, we show that the variability of maize yields will increase in most of the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries, and that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase. These results highlight the need for investments in breeding maize varieties that are more heat tolerant.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. These species ranged from almost-exclusive grazers to almost-exclusive browsers. Grass consumption was highly correlated with isotopic estimates of grass consumption, indicating that RRA conveys reliable quantitative information about consumption. Dietary overlap was greatest between species that were similar in body size and proportional grass consumption. Nonetheless, diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 crisis on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Many businesses are financially fragile, and the majority plan to seek funding through the CARES Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program, such as bureaucratic hassles and difficulties establishing eligibility. Our results suggest that the CARES Act will be critical to the survival of many small businesses.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks, which remove plastic fragments of millimeters in size. These sinks are likely to be a combination of processes in the ocean interior, such as fragmentation, and processes in the food web, such as ballasting. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of plastic debris in the ocean and is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. Reproductive output is a key metric of fitness in mammals. In this study, we use a comparative approach to understand the mechanisms by which external energy supplementation increases reproductive output. We find that all forms of external energy supplementation increase reproductive output, but the greatest increase is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of reproductive output in mammals. It also has implications for understanding the evolution of allomaternal care and domestication. Alpha-synuclein (α-syn) is a protein that is implicated in the pathogenesis of multiple system atrophy (MSA), a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. In MSA, α-syn accumulates in oligodendrocytes, a cell type that is essential for the maintenance of the myelin sheath. In this study, we show that the inflammatory protease caspase-1 is able to cleave α-syn at its C terminus, thereby promoting its aggregation. We also show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in oligodendrocytes and to protect motor neurons in a mouse model of MSA. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept for the potential of VX-765 to limit α-syn pathology and to protect neurons in synucleinopathies. This study also provides a rationale for the use of caspase-1 inhibitors in the treatment of synucleinopathies.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controls blood pressure, and controls inflammation. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The communication network is designed to be both local and global in nature. The local nature of the network allows for rapid responses to local stimuli, while the global nature of the network allows for the coordination of responses to stimuli from distant sources. The design of the communication network is important for the endothelium to control cardiovascular activity.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous data challenges. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking COVID activity, and for augmenting traditional public health reporting. The data are available for use by the public.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is thought to play a role in the health of the host. However, the potential for the microbiome to influence the health of the host is not fully understood. One way in which the microbiome may influence the host is through the production of natural products. Natural products are compounds that are produced by microorganisms and have a wide range of biological activities. In this study, we investigate the potential for anaerobic fungi to produce natural products that could influence the health of the host. We find that anaerobic fungi produce a variety of natural products, some of which are unique to anaerobic fungi. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi may be a source of natural products that could be used to influence the health of the host.

Social dominance is a key aspect of social behavior, yet the influence of personality traits on social rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait, directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. We conclude that mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens is crucial for social behavior and is critically involved in the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders.

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the current design approaches are limited by the availability of materials and the complexity of the structures. Here, we develop a synthesis strategy to design and manufacture composite structures that are composed of multiple materials with distinct behaviors. The synthesized structures are digitally designed to exhibit desired behaviors and are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. The structures are then assembled into architectures that exhibit highly complex and programmable behaviors. The proposed approach can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with specific behaviors for a wide range of applications. This work provides a new paradigm for the design and manufacture of mechanical devices with programmable behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. In humans, the hemoglobin system is regulated by the length of the day, a process known as chronobiology. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of human hemoglobin expression. IGF2BP1 is expressed in erythroid tissues and is down-regulated during fetal development. We show that IGF2BP1 mediates the developmental silencing of the adult hemoglobin system and that IGF2BP1 is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system in humans. These results suggest a mechanism for chronobiology of hemoglobin expression in humans. This work provides a potential target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies. It also provides a potential mechanism for the chronobiology of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The major drug class for treating hypertension is L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). LCCBs are used in the clinic, but their long-term safety is unknown. Our study shows that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling in vascular smooth muscle cells (VSMCs) and promote vascular remodeling. Our study provides a mechanism of LCCB action and suggests that LCCBs may be harmful in patients with advanced hypertension and/or cardiovascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way federal forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds, but did halt the decline of early-seral–associated birds. However, the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older forests, and early-seral bird populations declined in two ecoregions. These findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure. Our results also highlight the need for more effective monitoring of bird populations and the need for more robust models that incorporate the effects of fire and land-ownership changes. The use of electronic devices, such as computers and smartphones, has increased dramatically in the past decade. This study shows that the use of these devices in the hours before bedtime has a negative impact on sleep. Specifically, the use of electronic devices phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas cooling is a well-known abrupt climate change that occurred 12.9 ka. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. In this paper, we show that the Osmium isotope compositions of the magnetic grains and microspherules from the YDB sites are consistent with a terrestrial origin. In contrast, the Os in bulk sediments from the YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania is likely mixed with extraterrestrial Os. CTLA-4 is a key regulator of immune responses, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 deletion induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and autoimmunity, accompanied by organ-specific autoantibodies. However, in contrast to congenital deficiency, this was not fatal. CTLA-4 deletion induced preferential expansion of Treg cells, but T cells from CTLA-4–deficient inducible KO mice were able to induce the diseases in recipient mice. This indicates that CTLA-4 deficiency affects both central and peripheral tolerance and Treg cell-mediated suppression. Our results provide a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. This may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of autoimmune diseases. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, and to resolve the evolutionary history of beetles. Our results suggest that the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles, and that these insects may have diversified in response to the first independent origins of specialized plant feeding. Our results also suggest that the evolution of symbiont-independent lignocellulose digestion may have been key to the diversification of beetles. This process may have been a major driver of the extraordinary beetle radiation. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work may help to reduce the time and cost of antibody development and may be extended to other protein molecules. (Show more)

We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We found that larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE4 is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD, whereas APOE2 is associated with an ∼12-fold increased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform. The Earth's inner core is a solid ball of iron that is 1,700 km in diameter and 12 km in radius. It is the only solid region in the otherwise liquid outer core. The inner core is a mystery because it formed at a temperature that is too high for the iron to be stable in the hexagonal close-packed phase, which is the most stable phase of iron. This study shows that the inner core formed by a two-step process, in which the first step is the nucleation of the body-centered cubic phase of iron, which is the most stable phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our study provides a new perspective on the formation of the Earth and other rocky planets. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, and increased addictive behaviors. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might be a key mechanism underlying the addictive and negative emotional consequences of marijuana use.

Language is a uniquely human ability, and the brain’s neural mechanisms for comprehending it are only now beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most accurate deep learning models for language comprehension also predict the majority of neural activity associated with language processing. Our results provide a computational framework for understanding the neural basis of language comprehension, and they suggest that predictive processing may be a key mechanism for understanding the evolution of human intelligence.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been criticized for its instability. This paper shows that the instability is not due to the nature of deep learning but rather due to the difficulty of training algorithms. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a NN. This result provides a classification theory of conditions under which one can compute a stable NN. We introduce a fast iterative restarted network (FIRENET) that we prove is stable and numerically verify is fast and accurate. We also prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including a failure to understand exponential growth. This paper shows that the “classic” experiment that is often cited as evidence for this phenomenon is itself flawed. The study’s authors, however, were unaware of the experiment’s methodological problems, and the study’s conclusion was widely accepted. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are responsible for the two major forms of the disease, namely, lepromatous and tuberculoid leprosy. The genomes of these two bacteria have been sequenced, but their similarities and differences have not been fully appreciated. We have compared the genomes of these two leprosy bacteria and found that they are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides a framework for understanding the evolution of leprosy. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Entanglement and entropy are the two main resources for quantum information processing. They are also the two main ingredients of thermodynamics, the latter being the basis of the second law of thermodynamics. Therefore, understanding the evolution of entanglement and entropy is key to understanding the emergence of thermodynamics in isolated systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be completely understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, and we show that it is valid for a wide class of interacting systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives and has caused severe economic and social disruption. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors, which are associated with safety concerns. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is being developed by our group. The vaccine is based on a recoded version of the virus, which has been shown to be safe and effective in hamsters. The recoding introduces silent mutations in the viral genome, which are expected to improve the safety of the vaccine. The recoded virus is temperature sensitive in vitro, but grows robustly at the permissive temperature. The recoded virus is also highly attenuated in hamsters, and vaccination with a single dose of the recoded virus protects hamsters from all SARS-CoV-2–associated weight loss. These results support the potential of the recoded virus as a vaccine for mass vaccination programs. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. (truncated)

Plague is a disease with a long history of outbreaks and pandemics. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) was characterized by high mortality and recurrent epidemics, which led to the collapse of the European economy and society. The vector of the disease is still debated, with rodent and flea transmission being the most popular hypotheses. Here, we present a mathematical model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks better than models for rodent or flea transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study also provides a framework for studying the role of ectoparasites in the spread of infectious diseases. Cancer is a complex disease, and the search for effective therapies continues. One approach is to target the molecular pathways that are deregulated in cancer. In this study, we show that TRAP1, a mitochondrial molecular chaperone, is a potential therapeutic target. We show that TRAP1 is broadly expressed in normal cells, but is down-regulated in some cancers. We also show that TRAP1 is required for the metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1 may act as a tumor suppressor in some settings. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a useful target for cancer therapy. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin dynamics. It is known to sever actin filaments, but how it does so is not understood. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF binds to actin filaments and that filament curvature favors severing. Surprisingly, tension has no effect on ADF binding or severing. We also find that ADF-induced filament torque enhances severing. A simple model, which faithfully reproduces our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our work provides a mechanism for how ADF/cofilin, and other ADF-related proteins, sever actin filaments in cells. This mechanism may be relevant to other ADF-related diseases.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the brain may be a useful target for interventions aimed at reducing food intake. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The settlement history of Madagascar is complex, with a recent demographic growth and a sex-biased colonization. In addition, we found that the genetic structure of the Malagasy population is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a few centuries. This study provides a unique view of the settlement history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the settlement of other islands in the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

This is a form of emotional contagion, and it is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial, and some have suggested that it is difficult to observe emotional contagion in the real world. The ribosome is the central protein-synthesizing complex in the cell. It is composed of two RNA molecules, the small and large ribosomal subunits, and a set of proteins. The ribosome reads messenger RNA (mRNA) and translates the information into a protein. The mRNA is modified in many ways, and one of the most common modifications is the addition of a sugar ring to a specific nucleotide. This sugar ring is called pseudouridine (Ψ). We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a modest effect on translation. We also show that the presence of Ψ can lead to the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. This is important because the ribosome is constantly reading mRNA and translating the information into a protein.

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of health and behavioral outcomes, including better social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. These associations are not driven by factors such as prosperity or depressive symptoms, or by outcome levels before the measurement of worthwhile ratings. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of larger body sizes is a defining feature of the evolution of mammals. This study shows that the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is driven by the aquatic environment and is constrained by the energetic demands of the aquatic medium.

The common cold is the most common infectious disease in the world, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. Rhinovirus replicates more robustly at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at the core body temperature. Here, we show that mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at 37 °C than at 33 °C in primary mouse airway epithelial cells. We demonstrate that this temperature-dependent growth is due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of temperature-dependent growth in the common cold virus. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of these structures, and use this information to regulate surface-induced gene expression and pathogenicity. This is the first example of a bacterial mechanosensory system that uses pili as a sensor. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of mechanosensory systems in bacteria, and for the development of new strategies to combat bacterial infections. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. This has led to a substantial contamination of surface waters, which is of concern for the biodiversity of aquatic organisms. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation, which reveals that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the environment. Thus, the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced, and the use of pesticides that are more toxic to aquatic organisms should be avoided.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to infection. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 has been circulating in deer since the fall of 2020, coinciding with the peak of the deer hunting season. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We call for a more integrated approach to study the ecology of SARS-CoV-2, which will help us better understand the virus and prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a major concern because of the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, loss of biodiversity, greenhouse gas emissions, displacement of people, and changes to the food system, water quality, and agriculture. This paper examines the governance and compensation challenges of building large dams in the developing world and proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary component of the plaques that are the hallmark of the disease. However, the mechanisms that lead to Aβ accumulation and the subsequent development of plaques are not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons, which are the main cell type in the brain, are also vulnerable to Aβ toxicity. We demonstrate that Aβ-burdened neurons produce a variety of cytokines, which are potent inducers of microglial activation. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have important implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for AD. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species and is a main source of protein in the human diet. However, for thousands of years exploitation of chickens was confined to symbolic and social domains such as cockfighting. The question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. One of the most important questions is whether the folding of a protein is a single-step process or a multistep process. This paper provides evidence that the folding of a large protein is a multistep process. The protein studied is maltose binding protein, which is composed of two domains. The folding of the protein is studied by a combination of methods that provide high structural resolution. The results show that the folding of the protein is a multistep process.

The cellular concentration of dinucleoside tetraphosphates, often described as alarmones, increases in response to stress. The predominant enzyme responsible for decapping those RNAs, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable alarmones to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in Escherichia coli cells experiencing such stress, the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes N-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which bacteria reprogram gene expression during stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcome. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. Here we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is a key player in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and decrease sepsis-induced immunosuppression. Our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of this devastating disease. The results of such studies would also be of interest for other conditions in which arginine depletion is associated with immunosuppression. This article is protected by copyright. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. We introduce a continuous model of self-organized criticality (SOC) and show that it is a scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We show that our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties are limited by its small bandgap. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized, with a bandgap that fully vanishes, by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, with a bandgap that fully appears, by applying pressure. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are also relevant for other materials with a narrow bandgap, such as silicon. Our work is also relevant for the search for a metallization transition in graphene. Our work is also relevant for the search for a metallization transition in graphene.

The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. Here, we report the solution structure of a unique NCR peptide, which is a member of the largest family of legume-specific peptides. The structure of the peptide was largely disordered and highly dynamic. The peptide exhibited potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, including Botrytis cinerea and three Fusarium spp. It was able to penetrate the fungal cell wall and membrane, and induce reactive oxygen species in germlings. The peptide was able to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. The peptide was able to significantly reduce gray mold disease symptoms caused by the fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea in tomato and tobacco plants. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the molecular basis of sex differences. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use a combination of proteomics and isotopic labeling to characterize the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the sperm proteome undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and that they comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to the broader scientific community and will be of particular interest to those working on the male–female reproductive axis. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, to stop bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the pathophysiology of VWD. The force-dependent switching of VWF and platelets is a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and has been the target of only a few large-scale studies. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, and uses it to identify hundreds of viruses that are associated with human disease. The results provide a foundation for future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI process. The HSRL can simultaneously measure aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the scientific potential of the HSRL to investigate the ACI process. The observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface is important for understanding the evolution of life on Earth. The temperature of the surface has been inferred from isotopic data, but the results have been subject to question. We present a method for determining the temperature of the surface based on the thermostability of enzymes reconstructed from ancient DNA. The results are consistent with a decrease in the temperature of the surface over geological time.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and cause disease. One of the most important mechanisms is the binding of the parasite to the surface of the RBC. Here, we show that the binding of a parasite protein to the surface of the RBC alters the physical properties of the RBC, making it easier for the parasite to invade. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and suggests that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This could lead to the development of new strategies to combat malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its properties can be changed by external factors, such as strain. Here, we show that diamond can be completely metallized, without phonon instability, by strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without phonon instability, by strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work is expected to contribute to the development of diamond-based devices and applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may lead to the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of influenza virus disease. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words as it processes a sentence. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain remains unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal regions increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental step in the processing of language.

The Wnt signaling pathway is one of the most important pathways in development. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers differential responsiveness to the pathway. We believe that this differential regulation is a common feature in redundant gene pairs in vertebrates.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the search for new treatments is ongoing. One approach is to understand the neural circuits that control food intake and eating. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus (LH) induces eating in sated mice. We also show that this stimulation is mediated by a circuit that includes the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), and that this circuit is critical for the eating response. We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This work may lead to the development of new treatments for obesity. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth and yield, and the global demand for food is expected to increase by 50% by 2050. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop sustainable strategies to increase nitrogen use efficiency in agriculture. One promising approach is to engineer symbiotic interactions between plants and nitrogen-fixing bacteria. Here, we report the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen-fixing symbiosis, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This approach could be used to engineer nitrogen-fixing symbioses in a wide range of crops.

The Peruvian Amazon is the most deforested region of the Amazon, and the Peruvian government has made forest monitoring a priority. We study a community-based monitoring program that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities in the Peruvian Amazon. The results from our experiment suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals have evolved a wide range of hearing organs, but they are all part of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without a body. The spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, and the spider can hear by sensing the motion of the web. The spider can also adjust and regenerate the web to suit its needs. This study provides a unique model for studying the outsourcing and supersizing of hearing. It also provides a new way to study the sensing of air particle movements and the detection of acoustic sources. It may also inspire the design of novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. (Show more)

The health and climate impacts of human activities are intertwined. We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources. We find that a phaseout of fossil fuels can save 3.61 million excess mortality per year worldwide, and 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. The chemical influence of air pollution on aerosol particles contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the virus. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered protein can be expressed in large quantities in microbial cells, providing a platform for the development of vaccines that can be manufactured at a global scale. This engineered protein can also be used to design a virus-like particle vaccine, which can be manufactured at a smaller scale and may be more suitable for low- and middle-income countries. These findings provide a potential solution to the global vaccine shortage. (Show more)

The ligand–receptor interaction between secreted small ALKAL proteins and human ALK and related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK) is implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of neural crest-derived tissues. In the present study, we show that zebrafish ALK/LTK and ALKALs are involved in the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish larva. We further show that ALKALs are potent activators of ALK/LTK family receptors. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings have implications for the understanding of ALK/LTK family receptor function in human diseases. They also suggest that the ALKALs may be promising targets for the treatment of neuroblastoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been responsible for multiple outbreaks throughout the world. The emergence of this pathogen is a complex process that has been difficult to study due to the lack of ancient genomic data. Here, we present 17 ancient Yersinia pestis genomes from Eurasia dating to the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague’s evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—and support for Donald Trump, the 45th president of the United States. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. The agricultural transformation of the 20th century has led to the loss of 80% of the world’s grasslands and the conversion of 90% of the world’s arable land to intensive crop production. This has resulted in a massive release of carbon (C) to the atmosphere, with the potential to exacerbate climate change. In this study, we show that soil management practices that maintain or restore the ecological function of grasslands can sequester C in the soil. These practices include reduced tillage, diverse crop rotations, and the addition of manure. Our results highlight the potential of grasslands to mitigate climate change and the importance of maintaining and restoring grasslands for the benefit of the climate and the food supply.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for spillover and used this to rank the zoonotic potential of 887 viruses from 66,000 animals. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of viruses can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a blueprint for the systematic identification of viral threats and the development of tools to inform prevention and control.

Nectar is the reward that flowering plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards that plants offer to pollinators is nectar. One of the most common colors of nectar is red, which is attractive to vertebrate pollinators. However, the mechanism by which red nectar is produced is unknown. Here, we show that the red color of nectar is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify a second alkaloid, nesocodonine, which is produced in the same glands as nesocodin. We demonstrate that nesocodonine is also attractive to vertebrate pollinators. We further show that nesocodonine is produced by the same three enzymes that are necessary for the production of red nectar. Our findings provide insight into the evolution of red nectar and the discovery of a second alkaloid that is attractive to vertebrate pollinators. This work also demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a model for the evolution of red nectar in other plants.

The genetic structure of modern Europeans is strongly correlated with geography, but the processes that shaped it are still poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of men is mostly consistent with modern northern and central Europeans, but that of women is very heterogeneous and includes signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results suggest that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The global spread of infectious diseases is a major public health concern. In resource-scarce settings, such as Cambodia, the detection of undifferentiated fever cases is challenging due to limited laboratory capacity. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated fever cases in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our results highlight the potential of mNGS to detect undifferentiated fever cases and reveal the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the pathogen landscape and deployment of rapid public health response. This approach can be applied to other resource-scarce settings to better understand the pathogen landscape and mitigate the spread of infectious diseases. This article is protected by copyright. The lagging strand of the genome is replicated by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a unique perspective on the structure and function of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for lagging strand synthesis. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by an RNA polymerase ribozyme. In the laboratory, the activity of this ribozyme can be improved by in vitro evolution, but the ability to replicate RNA has not been demonstrated. Here, we show that an improved RNA polymerase ribozyme can replicate RNA, amplifying short templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a significant step toward the realization of the RNA world. (Show more)

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a key factor in understanding the spatial distribution of economic and social outcomes in cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that the patients with severe or critical COVID-19 had high levels of inflammatory cytokines, such as interleukin 6, and the immune cells, such as T cells and monocytes, were activated. Tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin 6 pathways, could reduce the levels of inflammatory cytokines and the activation of immune cells. It is effective in the treatment of severe or critical COVID-19.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The fungal xanthocillin biosynthetic gene cluster (BGC) has been shown to be involved in the acquisition of copper, but the role of the BGC products in copper homeostasis has not been established. Here we show that the xan BGC isocyanide products bind copper and that copper homeostasis is required for the antimicrobial properties of xanthocillin. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the evolution of interactions between fungi and microbes. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, on Mars is surprising because it is not a common mineral in the martian crust. Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is not uniform across the region. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees are not uniform across the region, and that this resistance is changing. Our findings can help decision-makers in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy to adapt to the changing spring-frost risk.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle) in the group Pygostylia. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In this study, we show that the color of some vertebrates is determined by the presence of a specific protein, which binds biliverdin, the pigment of the heme. This protein is most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study also provides a molecular basis for the evolution of green color in vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Breast cancer cells can be classified into two major populations, which differ in their ability to initiate tumor growth. One of these populations, the cancer stem cell (CSC) population, is responsible for the metastatic potential of the tumor. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5) in breast cancer cells. ALKBH5 expression is dependent on hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF) 1α and HIF2α, and results in enrichment of the CSC population. These findings have implications for the development of therapies that target the CSC population. (Read more)

The Bible is the most widely read book in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding the causes and consequences of the extinction. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle was highly variable during the extinction, and the recovery of the carbon cycle may have been a key factor in the recovery of the biota. The age model presented here will be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Read more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is applied to study the existence of equilibria in the game of life.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry and are of great importance in the understanding of the chemical world. In this paper, we show that the chemical properties of atoms, such as electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and we show that this is consistent with the pressure-induced metallization of the elements. We also show that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become electron acceptors. We show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are explicative and predictive.

Fire is a key ecosystem process, but its effects on climate are poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography, as caused by socioeconomic development, can have a large effect on fire activity and on the carbon cycle. Our results suggest that, in some cases, human demography may be the dominant driver of future fire regimes. This has implications for climate change mitigation, as well as for other ecosystem services provided by fire.

The symbiosis between squid and their luminescent bacteria is a model for the study of the evolution of mutualism. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan to its symbionts, which is catabolized only at night. This glycan is required for the persistence of the symbionts, which are dependent on it for their survival. We propose that this glycan may be a general nutrient that is provided to other symbioses, whose persistence depends on its catabolism.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is illustrated with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives, many of which are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to a wide range of domains and is likely to be useful for many applications in the social sciences and beyond.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague and its impact on human societies. It also offers a method for the reconstruction of past climate and plague dynamics. The sea star wasting syndrome (SSWS) is a disease affecting a large number of asteroid species on the Pacific Coast. The disease is characterized by rapid loss of tissue, and the loss of the entire animal is not uncommon. We show that the disease is caused by a virus, and that the virus is transmitted by starfish. The virus is also found in the plankton, sediments and in non-starfish echinoderms, suggesting that the virus is spread by the movement of water. The virus has been present in the past, and is therefore likely to have been present when the asteroids were introduced to the Pacific Coast.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. Crop experts are the eyes and ears of farmers, and their knowledge is critical for monitoring crop conditions and predicting crop yields. However, crop experts are not a part of the agricultural value chain, and their knowledge is not captured in the data that is used to monitor crop conditions. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition (CPC) survey, which is the primary source of information on crop conditions, can be improved by incorporating the knowledge of crop experts. We show that the CPC reflects the subjective perception of many surveyors at different locations, but the underlying models that describe the reported crop status are statistically robust and maintain similar characteristics across different crops, exhibit long-term stability, and have nation-wide validity. We demonstrate how this index can be used to monitor crop conditions and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of harnessing the power of “people as sensors” to improve agricultural monitoring.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major flux in the global carbon cycle, yet its response to climate change remains uncertain. In this study, we synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.
