The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has been a major advance in the study of materials. The discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear test, the “Trinity test,” is a unique event in the history of science. The discovery of the oldest known anthropogenic quasicrystal in the red trinitite, the first nuclear test photograph, and the discovery of the oldest known nuclear test photograph in the first nuclear test film, all provide a unique window into the history of the first nuclear test.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, converting solar energy into chemical energy that is used by all life. The conversion of solar energy to chemical energy is achieved by the capture of light by chlorophyll, the conversion of light energy to chemical energy, and the storage of this energy in the form of ATP and NADPH. The chlorophyll molecule is modified to form a ring structure, the formation of which is the focus of this study. The ring is formed by two unrelated enzymes, one from bacteria and one from plants. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS may be a consequence of the disease-related progressive loss of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The photonic crystals can be used to control the interactions between atoms, which can be used to study many-body physics. The photonic crystals can also be used to control the emission of light from atoms, which can be used to study spontaneous emission. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the role of aquatic habitats in this diversification is still controversial. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from lithographic limestone deposits in the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This fossil material has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, as it can help us understand the origin of new diseases and how they may evolve in the future. Here we present the genomes of ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These results are important for our understanding of the evolution of viruses and the origin of human diseases. (Show more)

Sea level is rising around the world, and the rate of rise is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of sea level rise over the last 25 y, which is 0.084 ± 0.025 mm/y2, or 0.84 ± 0.25 cm/y. This is the first time a quadratic has been used to estimate the rate of sea level rise over a period of time. The quadratic estimate is in good agreement with the IPCC 5th Assessment Report (AR5) model projections.

Pain is a major public health problem, with a large economic cost. In this paper, we show that pain is increasing in the United States, with tomorrow’s elderly reporting less pain than today’s midlife. This is a mystery, and it is important to understand the causes. We show that the erosion of working-class life is a likely explanation.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and dynamics of this defining species for the β-elimination and replacement reaction. The results highlight the importance of the crystallographic waters in the active site and the role of the α-aminoacrylate hydroxyl leaving group in the reaction pathway. The results also show how the chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why one substrate is able to react, while another is not. These results are important for understanding the mechanism of this and other β-elimination and replacement reactions. This work also demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment or vaccine for MERS. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS infection in a nonhuman primate model. Remdesivir is currently being tested in a clinical trial, and the data presented here support the use of remdesivir in the context of this trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study provides a proof of principle for the use of remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. The data also suggest that remdesivir may be effective in other coronaviruses. The symbiosis between squid and their luminescent bacteria is a model for the study of the evolution of mutualism. In this study, we show that the squid provides a single glycan to its symbionts, which are located in the squid’s symbiotic organ. The glycan is delivered in a cyclic manner, and its catabolism is required for the persistence of the symbionts. This glycan is the only one that the squid provides to its symbionts, and it is the only one that is catabolized in the symbiotic organ. We propose that other animal hosts may similarly regulate the activities of epithelium-associated microbial communities through the strategic provision of specific nutrients, whose catabolism modulates conditions like pH or anoxia in their symbionts’ habitat. This study provides a new perspective on the evolution of symbiosis and the role of glycans in the establishment and maintenance of mutualism. This paper reports on a series of experiments and a field trial that tested the impact of a brief, online intervention to encourage teachers to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. The intervention was evaluated in three districts, in three states, and in three school systems. The results show that the intervention halved year-long student suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention. This work has implications for the future of school discipline and for the future of education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA lesions that can interfere with the function of the genome. The present study provides mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. The results from this study are important for understanding the molecular mechanisms of mutagenesis and repair of alkylated DNA lesions.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe respiratory disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Virions must first be secreted from virus-producing cells, and then bind to target-cell receptors. We show that sequential proteolysis of the S glycoproteins contributes to MERS-CoV infection. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. These findings suggest that the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. Understanding the role of sequential proteolysis in other viruses may lead to the development of new strategies for controlling viral infection. (truncated)

The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the world’s population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these impacts. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. This paper describes a series of experiments and observational studies that show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals offered in a cafeteria can increase the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals by 40% or more. This is a simple and cost-effective way to reduce meat consumption and improve population health and the environment. The results also suggest that it may be possible to achieve this level of change without a rebound effect, in which diners choose less meat overall. These results have implications for the design of policies to promote more sustainable and healthy diets. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for engaging the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of breast cancer cells expressing oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the cancer cell surface and its potential as a therapeutic target. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that is unlikely to have a significant impact on the electoral process.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with a high mortality rate and a lack of effective treatments. The role of the viral accessory proteins in the pathogenesis of the disease is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. This study provides a molecular basis for understanding the role of ORF8 in the disease and may lead to the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema, which is a life-threatening condition. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats. We also show that this effect is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the pathophysiology of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The scientific enterprise is based on the idea that we can learn from data. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its challenges. In this paper, we describe a challenge that arises when we have a large dataset and we use a sophisticated statistical model to analyze it. The model allows us to “cherry pick” the strongest associations. We show how this can lead to false conclusions about the strength of associations. We describe how to address this challenge and illustrate our approach with three examples: forward regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The development of vascular networks is a critical step in the regeneration of organs, such as the liver. However, the generation of vascular networks is difficult to achieve in vitro. Here, we show that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of vascular networks in vitro and in vivo. This study provides a new approach for the generation of vascular networks and may be useful for the regeneration of organs. Furthermore, ETV2 may be a useful target for the treatment of vascular disorders. This study may also provide a new approach for the generation of endothelial cells for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

Receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) are important signaling molecules that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes. In the past decade, two additional RTKs have been identified as oncogenes: anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk). Here, we use zebrafish as a model system to explore the physiological function and to characterize in vivo links between Alk and Ltk with their ligands. We show that zebrafish deficient in augmentor ligands display a severe defect in iridophore patterning. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. Our results provide insights into the physiological role of these ligands and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells caused glucose intolerance due to impaired insulin secretion. STING deficiency in β-cells decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Moreover, Pax6 was the transcription factor that might be associated with defective GSIS in STING-βKO β-cells. These data revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (Show more)

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The viral genome is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. The selective packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the replication of the virus. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an avian influenza virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is characterized by the formation of atherosclerotic lesions in blood vessels. The development of these lesions is a result of the interaction of multiple factors, including genetic and environmental factors. However, the role of the hemodynamic environment in the development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been fully understood. In this study, we demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by the disturbed flow is a critical factor in the development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results provide a mechanistic understanding of the role of the hemodynamic environment in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the prevention of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a new perspective for the development of athero-protective drugs.

Wildfires are a natural part of the ecosystem, but they can also be a threat to human life and property. In the United States, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-started fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards. We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also suggest that the physical appearance of neighborhoods may be a useful indicator of the economic and social health of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides, but their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms that determine the severity of the disease are not fully understood. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid rise of viremia, the short duration of the eclipse phase, and the rapid clearance of the virus. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment and to assess the potential benefit of early treatment. The model can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are threatened by a variety of human activities and climate change. One of the most severe threats is the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis, which is triggered by heat stress. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that separates the host from the external environment. In the absence of tumors, the epithelium maintains a healthy balance between commensals and the immune system. However, in the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes dysfunctional, leading to a dysbiotic microbiome and a loss of homeostasis. Our experiments identify a mechanism by which the microbiome can trigger a regenerative response in the tumor-bearing epithelium, which in turn can trigger a microbiome response that further stimulates tumor growth. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of how the microbiome can influence tumorigenesis. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new strategies to treat cancer. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. Chemotherapy is the main treatment for breast cancer, but the response to chemotherapy is heterogeneous, and many patients do not respond to chemotherapy. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are important for the maintenance of breast cancer stemness. Finally, we found that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab was more effective than treatment with either chemotherapy alone. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The timing of the onset of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is one of the most important climate events of the past 100,000 y. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation was likely responsible for a large-scale stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn led to a poleward shift of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and a rapid advance of the Southern Hemisphere ice sheets.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also shows that freshwater fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve fishery management and protect the benefits that rivers provide to people. This includes the conservation of freshwater biodiversity, the protection of downstream ecosystems, and the provision of low-cost protein for the poor.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining characteristic of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this regenerative capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery provides a powerful platform for the discovery of genes that control the regenerative capacity of the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the evolution of genomes and the transmission of genetic information. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, using a population sequencing approach. We find that recombination is highly variable across the genome, with some regions experiencing many crossovers, while others experience none. We also find that recombination is polarized, with the highest rates occurring near the start of genes. These results are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the patterns we describe may be ancient and conserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of a number of networks, each with a specific function. However, the number of networks is not fixed, and new ones are being discovered. Here, we show that the dominant network in the healthy brain is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. We also show that the dominant network in healthy subjects is deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality is partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which we call the 5′ NAD+ cap. We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is not found on pre-mRNAs that are 5′ end-processed, suggesting that the 5′ NAD+ cap is not a posttranscriptional modification. The 5′ NAD+ cap may regulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications. We show that epigenetic DNA-me alterations at specific loci persist in blood mononuclear cells for several years during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of the recently identified cancer antigen, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), in TNBC is unknown. Here, we show that FSIP1 is expressed in the majority of TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a target for the management of this disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous compounds to the overall flavor is unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functional integrity of the Earth’s ecosystems. However, these two threats are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for our ability to predict the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation, and its neurons can be classified into several types based on their activity patterns during exploration. These types are thought to correspond to different aspects of the internal representation of space. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of MEC neurons in freely moving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to be responsible for the formation of a grid-like internal representation of space, are anatomically distinct from other cell types. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of MEC cell types and will be useful for understanding the formation of the internal representation of space. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The underlying cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here we show that the dopamine system is also affected in a different way in the human brain. We found that the dopamine-containing nigral system is affected in a different way in the human brain. We found that the dopamine-containing nigral system is affected in a different way in the human brain.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection with others. We also seek to understand others, and we do so by reading their minds. In this paper, we show that the way we read minds is by looking at the speed at which our minds respond to others.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also responsible for maintaining a stable heart rate in the face of changes in blood pressure and other hemodynamic demands. The SAN is a highly specialized cell, and its function is regulated by a number of factors. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the function of the SAN. STIM1 is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and its deletion in mice results in a loss of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores in the SAN. This loss of Ca2+ stores results in a loss of heart rate, and the heart rate is further reduced by an exaggerated autonomic response to acetylcholine. These studies reveal a role for STIM1 in the regulation of SAN function. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, the function of Si in plant physiology has been debated for decades. Although Si has been shown to confer resistance to insect herbivores, the underlying mechanism is still unclear. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances resistance of rice plants against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to protect rice plants from insect herbivory. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of ether lipid metabolism and macrophage activation.

Language is a complex cognitive ability that involves the ability to integrate and store information over short periods of time. Here we propose a computational model of language processing that is based on the adaptive modulation of neuronal firing rates. We show that this mechanism can support memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order which makes it suitable for temporal integration in sequence processing within the language domain. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in the field of plant biology. This is due to the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells and poses the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery in plants. Here, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and location of the siRNA attachment locus on the DNA nanostructure are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the siRNA attachment locus. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of a new class of tools for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to the health of lakes and coastal ecosystems worldwide. In the United States, the majority of nutrient inputs to lakes come from nonpoint sources, such as agricultural fields and urban areas. However, these sources are often diffuse and difficult to target for management. In this study, we show that small tributaries of large lakes can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should focus on small tributaries to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies around the world.

We study the dynamics of a chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is highly selective with respect to the chemical concentrations it can access. We find that the dynamics of the system are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of the environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a ratchet, but in this case the ratchet is driven by the environment itself, rather than by an external force.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that the disruption of NMDA receptors, which are the primary excitatory receptors in the brain, can change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex and alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We then show that these changes can be used to predict the onset of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDA receptor antibodies. They also suggest that the same circuit parameters that are tolerated in the control condition can become critical in the presence of the disease. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. The cause of this warming is unknown, but it is likely due to human activities. To understand the causes of this warming, it is important to understand the causes of past warming events. Here, we present a case study of a past warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this warming event was caused by a rapid injection of organic matter into the ocean, which caused anoxia and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. This study provides insights into the mechanisms of past warming events and can help us understand the causes of the current warming. (Show more)

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the evolutionarily conserved exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study not only provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation but also offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. The study also offers a potential explanation for the evolution of the exocyst complex. The N terminus of the EXO70 protein is likely to be involved in the regulation of exocytosis. Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a key component of sex differentiation in many organisms. In vertebrates, sex determination is often a single locus, but in some species, multiple sex determination alleles interact to produce more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles interact to produce four possible sex classes: ZZXX females, ZWXX females, ZWXY females, and ZZXY males. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits, and that the introgression of a newly acquired sex determiner can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-generated adducts of vitamin A. We show that the intracellular levels of iron, which are elevated in the retina, promote the oxidation and degradation of these adducts. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. The results also suggest that the addition of iron chelators to current therapies for age-related macular degeneration may be beneficial. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Predators are the main drivers of biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. However, the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, have evolved a modular morphology that allows them to capture prey using specialized structures that are dedicated to prey capture. Our results show that siphonophores have evolved to capture different prey types, and that the evolution of siphonophore specialization has been linked to the evolution of their morphology. These findings help us understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide insights into the evolution of predator morphology and the diversification of predatory niches.

The human hand is a complex and highly specialized structure. The evolution of the human hand has been a focus of intense study for many decades, but fundamental questions remain about the origins of the derived features that characterize the modern human hand. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand fossil from East Africa that preserves the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand that is absent in early hominins. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has important implications for our understanding of the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like tool use. (Read more)

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic pathways that supports cell growth is the one-carbon unit cycle, which is supported by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we report the discovery of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, which block cancer cell growth in vitro and in vivo. We also report a surprising finding that cancer cells in one particular cancer type, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, are uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. This finding provides a potential target for the treatment of this cancer. The discovery of this dependence on SHMT activity is a significant advance in our understanding of the metabolic vulnerabilities of this cancer. This work also provides a proof-of-concept for the use of small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1/2 as a cancer therapeutic. This approach has the potential to be broadly applicable to other cancers. This study provides evidence that deforestation can have negative impacts on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. The results have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. The study also highlights the importance of considering the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, particularly in rural areas of low- and middle-income countries.

Modern agriculture is a highly mechanised system, with the weight of farm machinery now exceeding that of the largest land animals that walked Earth. This has led to a chronic compaction of the soil, which is now at risk of irreversible damage. We show that the weight of farm machinery has increased so much that the subsoil is now at risk of compaction. We developed a global map of subsoil compaction susceptibility, which shows that 20% of arable land is at risk of subsoil compaction. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest land animals, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This study highlights the need for a more sustainable use of farm machinery and the need to consider the ecological footprint of modern agriculture.
